basics.name: Stefan Eduardo Lütschg Espinosa
basics.label: Biomedical Engineer
basics.summary: Stefan hails from Santiago, Chile and Miami, Florida. He is currently in his second year at Boston University working on his Bachelor of Science Degree in Biomedical Engineering.

work.summary: 'The goal of research in the Brain and Vision Research Laboratory is to understand the mechanisms mediating human visual perception in healthy and damaged human brain, long-term plasticity and short-term dynamics in networks of the adult normal and damaged (from stroke) cortex by using interactively multimodal imaging (fMRI, MEG), psychophysics, and biologically constrained computational modeling.'
responsibilities: Currently working on a psychophysical experiment involving Visually Guided Navigation using the Unity 3D game engine and C#.
The goal of this experiment is to be able to use it with medical imaging techniques such as MEG.
Ran stage management for School of Music ensemble concerts, student & faculty recitals, and masterclasses
Set up for events, ensured all events ran smoothly, and communicated with performers to solve performance related problems quickly and efficiently

volunteer.summary: Worked during the summers of 2015 and 2016 as a Teaching Assistant to the English department at this high school based in Quirihue, Region de Ñuble, Chile
highlights: Students won local English Spelling Bee competitions both years I worked there.

awards.title: Boston University Presidential Scholarship
awards.summary: Each year, the Board of Admissions awards the Presidential Scholarship to our incoming first-year students who demonstrate exceptional academic achievement. In addition to being among our most academically talented students, Presidential Scholars demonstrate excellence beyond the classroom and are leaders in their schools and communities. This $25,000 tuition scholarship is renewable for up to four years of undergraduate study at BU.

publications.name: Temperature Control for Tissue Engineering
publications.summary: Design & build a prototype for a temperature regulating enclosure that will heat up a standard 96-well plate used on a microscope platform. Develop code using an Arduino board to collect temperature information from 4 temperature sensors, display Maximum, Minimum, & Mean temperatures on an LCD screen, and regulate the process of heating a nickel-chromium wire
